Posts.Content: geyser wrote: I posted a while ago regarding plans for an excisional biopsy using mri wire localization.  I found a hospital and surgeon who readily agreed with the plan.  Having just had the surgery, things seem OK now.   The biggest regret I had, and unfortunately this is all after the fact now, is that I was too trusting with the surgeon (who was very kind) throughout and did not specifially asked about his involvement and presence during surgery.  I was aware that this was a teaching hospital and understood the involvement of interns and residents, but I am now almost certain that my "supposed" surgeon, whom I waited months to see for to his reputation, was not involved in the operation.  I was drugged once inside the operation room and did not see the surgeon come in, and when I woke up in recovery, I was told to be ready to go home.  I did not see or talk to the "doctor" who supposedly operated on me the whole day of the operation.  My family is completely convinced that my surgeon did not do it and is not happy at all. I don't want to seem difficult, but I must let my disappointment out.  It seems it's very very hard to find a doctor who would be completely forthright and honest with you, in all aspects of your treatment.  Nothing can be presumed nowadays, not even if it's totally reasonable.  In all of my contact with the team and the surgeon, I was always under the impression that the surgery would be performed by the surgeon, and never received a hint as to having someone else operate. I still thank the people who cared for me, and hope this is the last that I will need to see them again.  I hope I am wrong in my assumptions regarding my operation.  Trust broken can never be truly repaired. Posts.Content: Jul 21, 2011 12:21PM - edited Jul 21, 2011 12:31PM by geyser Hi NatsFan, I have decided that I will definitely ask during the post-opt appointment.  Even though I knew I would be haveing a duct excision, after the surgery I still wished to know what the surgical outcome was, i.e. how many ducts were removed?  Did they take out both lumps?  How much tissue was removed?  It's very frustrating I could not get any of those answers after surgery.   I know the anesthesiologist was a 4th year intern but when I did the wire placement procedure, I had the same experience you mentioned -- the attending introduced herself and asked my name, DOB, what I was there for.  So when the operation turned out that way, I was immediately suspicious, and, like I said, very disappointed.

Posts.Content: Jul 22, 2011 03:31PM geyser wrote: Apparently, there's a term called "Ghost Surgery" (if you type that into Google, there's a great deal of info on this topic) that represents exactly what I think happened to me.  Some research indicates that at teaching hospitals, anywhere between 50%-90% of elective surgeries are performed by residents.  Without full, explicit disclosure (not the generic consent form that vaguely mentions "may participate"), I think this is very unethical.   If this bothers you and you are heading into a teaching hospital, please make sure to discuss the specifics with your surgeon beforehand.
